numbered_ace_sentences: 1. In many countries, young people are more optimistic about the development of the world than elderly people.
2. In the US, about 70% of young people believe that the world is getting better.
3. In the US, about 30% of elderly people believe that the world is getting better.
4. In the US, there is a huge difference between young people and elderly people.
5. In Indonesia, young people and elderly people have relatively even numbers of people who believe that the world is getting better.
6. In India, young people and elderly people have relatively even numbers of people who believe that the world is getting better.
7. In Nigeria, young people and elderly people have relatively even numbers of people who believe that the world is getting better.
8. In less developed countries, a higher percentage of people say that the world is getting better.
9. I wonder why a higher percentage of people in less developed countries say that the world is getting better.
10. People in less developed countries see their own lack of development.
11. People in less developed countries see many improvements in the world around them.
12. People in less developed countries may perceive improvements in the world as greater than people in more developed countries perceive these improvements.
13. The graph poses many questions about perspective.
14. The topic of improvement is perspective-based.
15. I am part of the younger generation.
16. It is uplifting for me that many young people have positive outlooks on the world.
17. The title of the graph is: Optimism: the new divide between generations.
